value.title: Power BI Premium Query Profiling with DAX Studio and SQL Profiler
value.excerpt: Patrick looks at how you can use DAX Studio, or SQL Profiler, to do query profiling on Power BI Premium. This can help you debug query performance and more. value.excerpt: Catching up on the last two week. We had a big post regarding updates to the Power BI service. value.title: Building a Virtual Relationship in Power BI   Basics of TREATAS DAX Function
value.excerpt: TreatAs is an interesting function with multiple use cases in Power BI. I thought it is good to explain it in a set of videos, the first one here is about what the TreatAs function is and how it can help to build filters and a virtual relationship between two tables. Let's see how you can use this function.
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/YCJjeD8wz5c" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Caution When Using Variables in DAX and Power BI
value.excerpt: I have written another blog post about variables previously and explained how useful variables are. Variables in DAX are helpful in both readability and also the performance of your code. However, there are scenarios that you have to be careful when you use variables. Because variables are stored, they
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Vzgdw1EAMZI" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Combining Tables in Power BI   Union Except and Intersect in DAX
value.excerpt: Power Query is often the engine used for combining data tables, especially using Merge or Append. However, sometimes, you might need to do that operation in DAX. An example of that is when you want to create that combination only virtually as part of a measure calculation that evaluates dynamically.
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IPziqmQgJFw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Create a subset of the table in Power BI and add calculations using SELECTCOLUMNS DAX Function
value.excerpt: Previously I explained the AddColumns function as a function that adds one or more columns to the existing table, In this article and video, I'll explain another similar and useful function with slightly different behavior: SelectColumns, and you will learn how you can use it in Power BI and DAX. Download

value.title: Create a Table with A to Z Character Values in Power BI Using DAX
value.excerpt: I have explained previously that you can use GenerateSeries function in DAX to create a list of number, date or time, or even currency values. However, sometimes you might need to create a list of text values. Such as alphabet; from "a" to "z" lowercase, or uppercase. The good news is that you can do

value.title: DAX Measure in the Axis of the Power BI Report
value.excerpt: If you even need to show your DAX measures in a chart without a dimension to slice and dice it, you wonâ€™t get a great experience in the visual. In this video, Iâ€™ll share a trick that you can use to have a nice visualization like what you see in the above screenshot. Download the file and study more from

value.title: Day of Year and Day of Quarter   DAX calculations for Power BI
value.excerpt: Power BI has some built-in, easy-to-use DAX functions to get the Day of Month and Day of the week, but nothing for Day of Year and Day of the quarter. These calculations, however, are very simple and easy to implement using other functions. This short blog and video explain a method to calculate those
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ulT8HtF4gT0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Dynamic Banding or Grouping in Power BI   Using DAX Measures   Choose the Count of Bins
value.excerpt: Banding (or binning or grouping) is a scenario that can be implemented both statically and dynamically in Power BI. Dynamic banding means selecting the bin (or band) configuration, and the banding changes based on the user selection of the slicer. Imagine that we have a count of customers by their age
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/LaBmDaf_PPM" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Dynamic Banding or Grouping in Power BI â€“ Using DAX Measures â€“ Choose the Size of Bins
value.excerpt: In the previous video, I explained how to create dynamic bins by choosing the count of bins in a slicer in the Power BI report. In this video, I'll explain, how you can do it the other way around, which is by selecting the size of the bin, you will have bins and buckets dynamically generated. Download
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cbxVCa5lAcw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: FILTER Function in DAX and Power BI   Apply Custom Filter to Calculations
value.excerpt: You can apply filtering to visualization elements. However, sometimes filtering has to be done on specific calculations. This can come in handy especially when you want to compare values of other items with specific items. In this article and video, Iâ€™ll explain how to use the FILTER function in DAX

value.title: Find a Text Term in a Field in Power BI Using DAX Functions
value.excerpt: In Power BI, there are multiple ways of searching for a text term inside a text field, you can use Power Query for doing this operation or calculations in DAX. In this video, I'll explain some functions in DAX that you can use to do this calculation. Most of these functions can be used inside a measure

value.title: Find Lost Customers Using Power BI and DAX
